Maria Alma has been in this business for 2 years and sells a variety of items such as soap, fabric conditioner, canned goods, coffee and other groceries.

In the future, Maria Alma would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase additional items to sell like canned goods, snack foods, and other groceries.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy more cabbages and beans for sale.

loans.name: Anilyn

texts.en:
Anilyn is a 28 year old woman and has two children. Both children are in school.

Anilyn is in the agricultural business raising pigs in the Philippines. She requested a 6,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy feed, vitamins, and other supplies to raise her livestock.

She has been raising pigs for five years now, and has borrowed six times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

In the future, Anilyn would like to save enough money so she can afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy feed, vitamins, and other supplies to raise her livestock

loans.name: Oscar

texts.es:
Oscar, de 67 años de edad, depende de padres agricultores, que se dedicaban a cultivar caña de azúcar y tenían trapiche donde la procesaban, también trabajaban mucho con ganado; Oscar, desde que tenía 7 años de edad ya trabajaba fuerte y todo el día, ahora está casado.

Oscar, actualmente solo se dedica a trabajar con ganado, porque sus fuerzas ya no son las mismas y no puede realizar trabajos pesados y a las vacas solo tiene que ordeñarlas, va al potrero y compra y vende ganado.

El crédito lo necesita para comprar una novilla, pues no tiene el dinero y está interesado porque es de buena raza y considera que a futuro tendrá mejor producción de leche.

El sueña con dejar de trabajar y que el ganado lo cuiden sus hijos.
texts.en:
Oscar, age 67, depends upon the agricultural heritage of his parents, who cultivated sugar cane, and had a mill where they processed it. They also worked a lot with cattle, and Oscar, from the age of seven, worked hard all day long. Today, he is married.

Now Oscar only works with cattle, because he is not as strong as he used to be, and he can't perform heavy work. With cows, he only has to milk them, go to the pasture, and purchase and sell cattle.

He needs the loan to purchase a heifer, as he doesn't have the money, and he is interested because the heifer is a good breed which he thinks will give him better milk production in the future.

He dreams of retiring and having his children take care of the cattle.

loans.use: to purchase a heifer.

loans.name: Tae

texts.en:
Living in a wooden house located in Siem Reap province’s Srey Snom district, Tae is 48 years old and married. She has six children, only three of whom are still dependent on her. 

Tae and her husband are farmers who grow rice and plant cassava as the main business to support the family and they supplement the family’s income by raising chickens and working as a paid workers. Having been in the business for 36 years, they are able to make daily earning of 35,000 KHR per day and manage to save about 10,000 KHR each day. 

Her crop has been heavily destroyed by insects and this is the main challenge for her business. This is the fourth loan for Tae with Kiva’s partner, VisionFund. She completely paid back the past loans. Now she is applying for another loan to buy fertilizers and pesticide for her farmland and will also use some of it to spend on plowing the fields. She hopes this loan will enable her to extend her agribusiness and also grow her crops healthily so she can make more income to improve her living conditions.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and pesticide for her farmland and to plow the fields.

location.town: Siem Reap Province, Srey Snom district

loans.name: Jlg-004-Kurichi Group

texts.en:
Devagi is a mother of four children. She leads a group of three in Kulithalai, Tamil Nadu. She works hard to sustain her family. They have no access to toilets and therefore have to resort to open defecation using the false privacy of nearby fields and surrounding shrubbery. The women and their daughters are subsequently at risk of infection, molestation, and even insect or animal bites.

Seeking to improve her situation, she formed a group to apply for a loan of 42,000 INR. With the loan the borrowers will build toilets in their respective homes. Your loan will help these three hardworking rural Indian families to access basic sanitation, and consequently, safety, improved health, medical savings, and improved productivity.

loans.use: to build a toilet in their home.

loans.name: Somos Impacto 2006 Group

texts.es: Sofía  de 55 años de edad es casada y tiene 5 hijos. Ella Pertenece a la Alcancía Comunal “somos impacto 2006” la cual lo conforman 08 socias con deseos de  trabajar honradamente y progresar. Ella hace más de 10 años que tiene su tienda donde vende todo tipo de abarrotes. Gracias a su constante dedicación logro sacar adelante a  sus hijos. Su mayor deseo es que todos sus hijos sean profesionales. Solicitó el crédito para la compra arroz aceite fideos y azúcar. La Alcancía “somos impacto 2006”agradece a los Inversionistas de Kiva por el apoyo brindado. Sofía es la primera del lado izquierdo viste chompa color azul oscuro.
texts.en:
Sofía is 55 years old, married, and has 5 children. She belongs to the communal bank "Somos Impacto 2006" [We are the Impact 2006], which is made up of 4 members who wish to do honest work and advance themselves. For more than 10 years she has had a store where she sells all types of groceries. Thanks to her continuous dedication, she is able to support her children. Her deepest desire is for all her children to become professionals.

She is requesting this loan to buy rice, oil, noodles, and sugar. The communal bank "Somos Impacto 2006" thanks Kiva lenders for the support they offer. Sofía is the first woman on the left with the dark blue jacket.

loans.use: buy rice, oil, noodles, and sugar.

loans.name: Fatmeh

texts.en: Fatmeh is a 24-year-old, married Lebanese woman living with her husband and only child, who attends school. She cooperates with her husband, who is their main income provider, to fulfill the family's needs. She opened a clothing shop in 2010, where she offers a great variety of clothes for women at good prices. Today, she is requesting a loan from Kiva partner Vitas s.a.l to purchase a new collection of clothes so that she can improve her business operations and income.

loans.use: to purchase a new collection of clothes

loans.name: Perveen

texts.en:
Perveen is a married woman.  She deals in the business of selling animals. She buys animals (baby goats & calves) at low prices, raises them and then sells them in the market at higher prices. She makes enough through her business to contribute to the family income. She also sells milk to generate an extra amount of income. She needs to improve her business to bear her household expenses. 

For this reason, she contacted Kashf Foundation and applied for a loan of PKR 40,000 to purchase more animals to inflate her sales. She is very experienced and has good contacts in the market. With this loan, she will definitely expand her business and income level.

loans.use: to purchase more animals

loans.name: Herna

texts.en:
Herna is a married woman with two children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Herna is 37 years old and has two children are presently in school.

Herna has a fish vending making business in the Philippines. Herna requested a PHP 10000 loan amount through NWTF to buy more fish, sacks of salt, net and other materials for her dried fish making business.

Herna has been in this business for 8 years. She would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy more fish, sacks of salt, net and other materials for her dried fish making business

loans.name: Naseem

texts.en:
Naseem is a 45-year old married woman, living in the area of Lahore, Pakistan.
Naseem has requested a loan from Kiva’s field partner BRAC Pakistan for her husband's shoe store so he can buy gents' shoes for his shoe store. He has been selling ladies' fancy and casual shoes in his hometown. Most of his customers demand gents' shoes as well, but due to the lack of availability of funds, he can not purchase gents' shoes.

Therefore, Naseem has requested a loan so her husband can buy a variety of gents' shoes for reselling purposes. In this way, he can easily cope with the demand and abstain from the customers' disappointments.

His shop is situated in the shoe market and lots of other shoe stores are available there, which becomes the cause of tough competition. He dreams of moving his shop to another place to abstain from competition.

Through the investment of this current loan he can easily establish his shoe store and can enhance his savings so his dream can come true.
Naseem thanks Kiva, their honorable lenders and their field partner BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to buy a variety of gents' shoes for her husband's shoe store.

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia is a hardworking woman entrepreneur with four children.

She earns a living by pig fattening in the Philippines. She is borrowing PHP 30000 through NWTF to buy feeds and other supplies to raise her pigs.

She supplements this income with earnings from her farming rice.

Virginia dreams that one day  will be able to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy feeds and other supplies to raise her pigs

loans.name: Shaheen

texts.en:
Shaheen is 45 years old woman who lives in Rawalpindi, Pakistan, with her two sons and one daughter, who are in school. Her husband has been running her own business of clothes selling for 7 years.

Her husband needs to purchase different types of clothes in bulk for reselling purpose, but due to insufficient financial means he is unable to purchase these clothes. Therefore Shaheen is applying for a Kiva loan from its field partner BRAC Pakistan. So that she can assist her husband to purchase these clothes in bulk for his business. Her husband can also increase the size of his business and earn maximum profit with the help of this loan amount.

Shaheen is very thankful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to increase her husband's clothing business.

loans.name: Jlg-015-Kulithalai Group

texts.en: Parameshwari is a 42-year old mother of four. She has formed a self-help group with her friends in Kulithalai, in the rural part of Karur, in Tamil Nadu where they lives. All three group members work hard to support their families, and save diligently. However, their finances are not adequate for them to access basic necessities like toilets in their homes. They have to trek long distances at dawn to use the fields to relieve themselves. This puts them at risk of infection, molestation or attack, and even insect or animal bites. Seeking to improve their situation, they seek a loan of INR 42000, to build toilets in their homes. As they begin to enjoy the benefits of basic sanitation and their families improve in health and they will be able to save on medical expenses. Your loan will provide all three families access to improved hygiene and a better way of life.

loans.use: to construct a toilet and improve sanitation facilities in her home

loans.name: Musiri South Jlg - 029 Group

texts.en:
Akilandeswari is a 35-year-old woman who represents the group Musiri South Jlg -029. She lives with her family in the Tiruchirapalli district, in Tamil Nadu.

Akilandeswari engages in daily wage labor and earns INR 4,000 every month with her income. She is unable to manage the household expenses of the family. She faces difficulties in making ends meet.

Akilandeswari is trained in making foot mats. Now, she wants to start her own business, making foot mats. She believes that it can be profitable enough to help the family lead a better and financially secure life.

Although she is willing to support her family, she lacks the funds required to start the business. She seeks a loan to buy the raw material to initiate her business. Similarly, the other members in the group also want funding to start their respective businesses. They are grateful to their lenders.

loans.use: to start a business, making foot mats.

loans.name: Bernardino

texts.es:
El socio Bernardino se dedica al negocio de venta de artesania,el socio es una persona trabajadora que por medio de este negocio el socio quiere sacar adelante a su familia,el sueño del socio es tener un local donde pueda vender la artesania.El socio solicita el crédito para comprar mantas y telares.

El socio está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
Bernardino sells artisan products. He is a hardworking person who wants to provide for his family by means of this business, and his dream is to have a shop where he could sell the artisan products.

He is requesting a loan in order to purchase blankets and weavings. He is happy about the loan, and he is committed to making his payments on time.

loans.use: to purchase blankets and weavings.

loans.name: Jacquiline

texts.en:
Jacquiline is a married woman. She describes herself to be flexible. She operates a retail business where she sells clothes. She has been involved in this business for 3 years. Her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be transport costs.

She will use the Kes 95,000 loan to buy more stock of clothes. She hopes that in the future, she will own rental houses and be a prominent business lady.

This is her fifith loan with SMEP Microfinance bank. Previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: buy more stock of clothes for selling

loans.name: Servet

texts.en:
Servet is 52 years old, married, and the father of four children: two boys and two girls. Together, they live in a village in the southern part of Kosovo. He supports his family through the food shop that they own, a family business where his wife also works. The shop sells a variety of beverages and food products to the community and is quite popular.

Recently, Servet had an accident and he had to sell his cow to get money for his treatment and medicine. He is requesting a loan to purchase another cow so that he can sell the dairy products in his shop and to others in neighborhood to supplement their income. The additional money he previously generated from the cow has helped him and his family to have a better life. He hopes in the future he will be able to expand his farm even more and add additional cows to increase his income. He thanks lenders for their support.

loans.use: to purchase another cow so that he can sell the dairy products in his shop and to others in his neighborhood.

loans.name: Amargot

texts.es:
Amargot, de 56 años de edad, estudio hasta segundo grado, debido a la situación económica de su familia no estudio, está soltera, tiene 3 hijos pero todos son mayores de edad y dos están acompañados, en su casa solamente vive ella y una hija.

Amargot, se dedica a vender antojitos como tamales y atol, decidió vender estos antojitos cuando tenía a sus hijos pequeños, de esa manera los saco adelante y pudo darles lo necesario.- El negocio le funciono y le pareció buena idea mantenerlo, es por eso que hoy en día tiene muchos clientes y le hacen pedidos y ya no necesita salir a vender casa por casa, hoy los clientes llegan a comprarle a su casa; pero además de tener este pequeño negocio, también se dedica a la agricultura en pequeño, gracias a las ganancias que le quedan de su negocio, puede sembrar maíz y frijol y cuando las cosechas son buenas vende de sus granos, para poder tener más ingresos económicos y tener lo necesario para ella y su hija.

Amargot, necesita el crédito para comprar una plancha para hacer pupusas y tortillas, además comprará harina de maíz, verduras y condimentos para la elaboración de los alimentos que vende, esto le permitirá facilitar su trabajo y elaborarlos con mucha agilidad, de esta forma podrá aumentar su producción y mejorar sus ganancias.

Amargot, sueña con mejorar su negocio e incrementar más sus ventas, además planea poder remodelar su casa y agrandarla más.
texts.en:
Amargot is 56 years old. She studied up to grade 2 and due to the economic situation of her family studied no more. She is single and has three children, all of them adults with two of them married. So she and her daughter live alone in her house.

Amargot works selling snacks like tamales and atole (a corn based drink). She decided to sell these snacks when her children were small. Doing this she raised them and could provide them with what was necessary. Her business worked for her and it seemed like a good idea to keep it going. For this reason she has many clients today who request orders so she doesn't have to go out and sell from house to house. These days the customers come to her house.

But besides her small business she also works in small scale farming. Thanks to the profits her business brings in she can plant corn and beans. When the harvests are good she sells her grains to have another income and have what she needs for her and her daughter.

Amargot needs the loan to buy a griddle to make pupusas and tortillas, and to buy corn flour, vegetables and condiments to make the foods she sells. This will allow her to make her work easier and make food quicker. This way she can increase her food production and improve her profits.

Amargot dreams of improving her business and increasing her sales. She also plans to remodel her house and make it larger,

loans.use: to buy a griddle to make pupusas and tortillas and buy corn flour, vegetables and condiments for the preparation of her foods.

loans.name: Janita

texts.en:
Janita is 53 years old and married with four children.

Janita works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF in order to purchase more stock of groceries to sell.

Janita has borrowed and paid 6 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for three years and also earns an income from fattening pigs.

Janita aspires to save enough money to expand her business and repair her family's home.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of groceries to sell.

loans.name: Zareena's Group

texts.en:
Zareena is a 39-years old married woman, living with her family in Lahore, Pakistan.
Her husband is a confectioner by profession and owns a bakery. He sells kinds of Pakistani sweets such as laddu, barfi, gulabjamun, rus gullay etc. Earlier his father was running this bakery but due to his old age her husband has taken over from his father and is looking after all the bakery's affairs.

He had been purchasing all the inventories on large quantity from a nearby bakery and selling it from his own bakery. Now he wants to prepare all the sweets by himself but he does not have basic ingredients for making sweets. Due to lack of availability of funds he is unable to buy the raw materials
.
Therefore, Zareena has requested a loan so that her husband can buy his desired ingredients for making sweets to sell. She thanks Kiva and field partner, BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to buy ingredients so her husband can prepare and then sell sweets from his bakery.

loans.name: Touch's Group

texts.en: Touch’s group lives in a rural village in Kampong Speu province in Cambodia. Touch makes a living cultivating rice and she also does extra work as a tailor to support her family. In their village there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water. Having a water filter at home will help each of the group members to safeguard the health of their families and save money on medical expenses and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

loans.use: To buy a water filter to provide safe drinking water for their family.

loans.name: Daveat's Group

texts.en: Daveat’s group lives in a rural village in Kampong Speu province in Cambodia. Daveat makes a living cultivating rice and he also does extra work as a tailor and construction laborer to support her family. In their village there is no reliable access to safe, clean drinking water. Having a water filter at home will help each of these women to safeguard the health of their families and save money on medical expenses and save time collecting fuel and boiling water.

loans.use: To buy a water filter to provide safe drinking water for their family

loans.name: Lucy

texts.es:
La socia Lucy se sigue dedicando al negocio de venta de gelatinas y también la socia vende huevo sancochado,la socia es una mujer muy trabajadora que por medio de este negocio la socia quiere sacar adelante a su familia,el sueño de la socia es tener un local donde puede vender los huevos sancochados y gelatinas. La socia solicita el crédito para comprar gelatinas y huevos.

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
Lucy continues with her business selling gelatinas (gelatin desserts), and she also sells boiled eggs.

She is a very hard working woman, who wants to provide for her family by means of this business, and her dream is to have a stall where she could sell the boiled eggs and gelatinas.

She is requesting the loan in order to purchase gelatinas and eggs. She is happy about the loan, and she is committed to making her payments.

loans.use: to purchase gelatinas (gelatin desserts) and eggs.

loans.name: Davlatali

texts.en: Davlatali is a hardworking man. He was born in a southern part of Tajikistan in 1965. He is living in village with his family. He is married and has four children. He and his wife are teachers. He has six yeas of experience tutoring students at university. The standard of their living is basic. He has bright children and all of them are active and helpful to their parents. Every year of his children's education he has to pay the tuition fee of their studies. This year he had some difficulties with saving up money for the children’s education. He decided to apply to KIVA and get money to pay education costs of his children. He is willing to be supported.

loans.use: to pay education costs of his children

loans.name: Loikjon

texts.en:
Loikjon is a careful father. He was born in northern part of Tajikistan in 1989 and is living in village with his wife and daughter. He is hardworking, goal-oriented, responsible and honest person. He started to do business two years ago.

Then he entered the university to get a higher degree education in Medicine. Their standard of living is poor. His parents cannot pay his tuition fee. The salary that he earns is spent on family needs.

He appealed to IMON asking a loan to pay his higher education costs. He wishes to get knowledge and have a good occupation in the future. He awaits Kiva lenders kindness and compassion.

loans.use: to pay his higher education costs for a degree in Medicine

loans.name: Estella

texts.en:
Estella is so grateful that she was granted loans in the past three years and has not once failed to pay on time. They have certainly helped sustain her store and thus helped in their daily sustenance and in helping her college and high school children. To augment her income, she started a food vending business which is doing well.

Estella trusts that she can again avail a PHP 50,000 loan to buy some grocery items such as rice, coffee, soda and rice noodles which she sells at retail. Half of the loan she will use to pay for fresh meat, veggies and condiments to prepare dishes for her food vending business. Although she is daily pressed for time in cooking her dishes, she is more than glad to serve her customers.

Estella's simple dream is to rent or own an eatery in a commercial area. She wishes for her children to finish college. Every week, she meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God which she studies .

 *All Center for Community Transformation (CCT) community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and repay Micro-Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items, beverages for her general store and ingredients for her food vending business

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel is one of those young smallholder farmers who are determined and are not limited by their age. He is an ever smiling youthful 30-year-old farmer from luanda, a remote village in the Kitale area of Kenya. Emmanuel is elegant and admirable in spirit and effort. He is a role model, a mentor, and an inspiration to many young farmers in his village because of his resilience despite personal challenges and his passion to support his family as a primary source of income. The living conditions in the Kitale area are very tough and one needs to have tough skin in order to survive. Emmanuel has always shown the resilience to beat all odds.

Because of the hardcore poverty in his village, Emmanuel started practicing mixed farming and has been doing it for the past 5 years. Emmanuel's sources of income are from producing vegetables, maize, and eggs. These products are very perishable and require timely delivery to the market, which is a problem for Emmanuel. The Kitale area has a poor road network and poor feeder roads that really hamper timely delivery of products to the market.

Emmanuel is kindly seeking a loan to buy a motorbike. With the motorbike he will deliver products to the market on time and reap more profits because the products will still be fresh. Emmanuel is very determined to succeed, and because he is very disciplined with finances, he plans to accumulate profits to provide a secure future for himself and for his parents. Emmanuel's dream is to provide a secure future for his family. Through your loan you will help him realize his dream.

Emmanuel promises to make his payments punctually and is thankful to all those who will support him in acquiring the motorbike, all he can tell them is "Thank You".

loans.use: to buy a motorbike, for the speedy transportation of his farm produce to market.

loans.name: Jlg-021-Thanneerpalli Group

texts.en:
Kasthuri is 25 years old and lives with her family of 8 in Kulithalai, Tamil Nadu. She works hard as a daily wage labourer to support her family. She finds it hard to sustain her family but she manages with her meagre income of INR 7,000. She and her family do not have access to a toilet at home, and therefore have to resort to open defecation using the false privacy of nearby fields and surrounding shrubbery. They are subsequently at risk of infection, molestation, and even insect or animal bites.

Kasthuri leads a group of 4 women who share the same problem. So, taking advantage of the awareness initiatives, they now seek a loan of INR 56,000 to build toilets in their homes. Your loan will help their families access basic sanitation, improved health, and safety. They will not only lead a healthier life, but also lead a more productive life.

loans.use: To improve sanitation facilities in their homes by installing toilets.

loans.name: Raed

texts.en: Raed is a 28-year-old, single man from Deir Al-Balah city in the Gaza strip. He lives with his family in a simple house. Because the economic situation in Gaza is not good, a few years ago Raed started his own business. He manages a stall for selling kitchen tools, and a cleaning agency. This is the only source of income for the family.  took a USD loan from Palestine for Credit & Development (FATEN). This loan will help him to buy a new collection of Cleaning materials for his stall. This will increase his sales and also his income.Raed appears in the photo.

loans.use: to buy a new collection of cleaning materials for his stall.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more goods to offer to his customers.

loans.name: Vicky

texts.en:
Vicky raises a small number of pigs which helps to meet the family's daily needs. She has earned more than expected and was able to repay her loan. She will use a new loan to buy feed for her pigs. She and her husband raise a few piglets until they reach their marketable age. They sell to the market and deliver to loyal customers.

Vicky's plan to the future is to save money and improve the quality of life they have.

loans.use: to purchase feed for her pigs.

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Every entrepreneur’s goal is to see their business succeed or grow. Evelyn, one of CCT's partners was granted a loan amount of P30, 000 and was able to use the amount for her sari-sari store business. She’s very grateful since CCT helped her a lot in the business and for the lenders who donated certain amounts. The money was used to buy additional stock like bottled drinks, grocery items, school supplies and other products. A sari-sari store is a Filipino term which means ‘variety’; it is usually found in barrios, cities, neighborhood or barangays where items or products are being sold by volume, kilo or by piece.

Evelyn aims to have a one-stop shop where she’ll have all of the items needed by the consumers. She is aware that competitors in this line of business are rampant. That’s why she is still contemplating ways on how to attract buyers/consumers. Turning her sari-sari store into a grocery store is one of her goals. Since it is her bread and butter, Evelyn exerts her effort and hard work for the business since this really helped her sustain her family’s needs and support her children’s education. Added capital will help her business flourish.

That’s why Evelyn decided to apply for another P40,000 this year to buy additional stock such as laundry products, drinks, toiletries, canned goods, school supplies and other items.

Despite being busy managing the business, Evelyn is still consistent in attending CCT group fellowship that consist of 10-15 individuals. This is where she can gain strength spiritually, where she hears testimonies from other CCT partners and is able to hear God’s word, study the Word of God, build social relationships with other partners, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy additional stock such as laundry products, drinks, toiletries, canned goods, school supplies and other items for her variety store

loans.name: Dorothy

texts.en:
Dorothy is a married woman with 2 children. She describes herself to be honest. She operates a retail business where she sells auto spares. She has been involved in this business for 2 years. Her business is located in a busy place and her primary customers are locals. She describes her biggest business challenge to be lack of enough stock to satisfy demand.

She will use the Kes 48,000 loan to buy more stock of auto spares. She hopes that in the future, she will have better living standards. This is her third loan with SMEP Microfinance bank. Previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: buy more stock of auto spares.

loans.name: Liberty

texts.en:
Liberty is a married woman with three children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Liberty is 25 years old and has one child still in school.

Liberty has a dried fish making business in the Philippines. Liberty requested a PHP 5000 loan amount through NWTF to buy more fish, sacks of salt, net and other materials for her dried fish making business.

Liberty has been in this business for 1 year. She would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy more fish, sacks of salt, net and other materials for her dried fish making business

loans.name: Pari Gull

texts.en:
Pari Gull is the responsible mother of 4 children. She lives in Rawalpindi, Pakistan. Her husband provides transportation services, driving a Taxi for the past 5 years. Her husband is responsible for supporting the entire family. Her husband's taxi needs maintenance; the current condition of his taxi is not good and he faces mounting maintenance charges on daily basis. Due to insufficient financial means, her husband is unable to repair his taxi. Therefore, Pari Gull has applied for a Kiva loan from its field partner, BRAC Pakistan.

With the help of this loan, Pari Gull's husband can easily afford the taxi maintenance costs and provide better transport services to increase his income. Pari Gull plans to start saving the profits from her husband's income to meet her family's needs in the future. Pari Gull is very grateful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to pay for maintenance of her husband's taxi.

loans.name: Cherry

texts.en:
Cherry is a 39-year-old married woman with one child. She is a very hardworking entrepreneur.

Cherry has a dried fish-making business in the Philippines. Cherry requested a loan of 10,000 PHP through NWTF to buy more fish, sacks of salt, net and other materials for her dried fish-making business.

Cherry has been in this business for 1 year. She would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy more fish, sacks of salt, net and other materials for her dried fish-making business.

loans.name: Annalle

texts.en:
Annalle is a married woman with three children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Annalle is 45 years old and has one child still in school.

Annalle has a dried fish making business in the Philippines. Annalle requested a PHP 5000 loan amount through NWTF to buy more fish, sacks of salt, net and other materials for her dried fish making business.

Annalle has been in this business for 10 years. She would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy more fish, sacks of salt, net and other materials for her dried fish making business

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet is a married woman, 51 years old with three children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur.

Juliet has a dried fish making business in the Philippines. Juliet requested a PHP 9000 loan amount through NWTF to buy more fish, sacks of salt, net and other materials for her dried fish making business.

Juliet has been in this business for 15 years. She would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more fish, sacks of salt, net and other materials for her dried fish making business

loans.name: Jlg-011-Vairaperumalpatti Group

texts.en:
The sanitation crisis in India is a result of poor infrastructure and lack of education. This group of 4, led by Logeshwari, living in Kulithalai, in the state of Tamil Nadu has understood the importance of having a toilet at home. But they do not have the means to build one.

Logeshwari, is 27 and works hard, earning daily wages to support her family of three. The household income is Rs 8000 and she works hard to ensure that they manage to lead a happy life with the little they have. The one thing she would like to change, however, is the fact that they lack a toilet at home.

With no access to a toilet, her family members have to walk long distances to answer nature's call in private: in dense bushes or isolated fields. The women and girls, seeking privacy, often resort to waking up before sunrise to relieve themselves. Due to this lack of sanitation facilities, they are at risk of infection and fall ill often, spending a significant portion of their savings on medical expenses each month.

So, taking advantage of the awareness initiatives, Logeshwari is seeking a loan to build a toilet at home. The other women in the group are in a similar situation and are also seeking loans to build toilets at home. Your loan will help these 4 hardworking rural Indian families to access basic sanitation, and consequently, safety, improved health, medical savings, and improved productivity.

loans.use: to construct toilets and improve sanitation facilities in their homes.

loans.name: Jlg-015-Ayyarmalai Group

texts.en:
34-year-old Vijaya from Kulithalai, in rural Tamil Nadu has no toilet at home or in the immediate vicinity. Vijaya is married and is a mother of 2 children. Vijaya's family is one of the millions affected by rural India's sanitation crisis. Without access to a toilet, her family has to walk long distances to relieve themselves in the false privacy of dense bushes or isolated fields. These unsanitary practices make them vulnerable to infections, and the lack of privacy exposes them to molestation or worse.

Joining hands with 3 others whose families face similar problems due to a lack of sanitation facilities, Vijaya has formed a group and is hoping to address this issue. Taking matters into their own hands, Vijaya and her group want to build toilets for themselves in their own homes. They seek a loan of INR 42,000 to cover the cost of raw materials and labor for constructing these toilets. Your loan will help these families access basic sanitation, improved health, and safety.

loans.use: to build toilets at home.

loans.name: Nice Clothes, Happy Life - N13Tsơnpsơn Group

texts.en:
Mrs Hạnh is 42 years old and she is married. She has had a business tailoring clothes for more than 10 years. Hạnh lives in Thanh Hoa city, a urban town in Thanh Hoa province. Her family is a low-income household in village.

The main hardship that Hạnh faces is lack of capital. She is requesting a loan to expand her business tailoring clothes and to purchase materials to sew more clothes.

Before borrowing from Thanh Hoa microfinance institution, her family does not have enough money to do business and cover the family cost.
In 2013, Hạnh joined Thanh Hoa microfinance institution. Since then, she could buy more materials and a sewing machine to improve her business.

Hạnh has successfully repaid 3 loans from Thanh Hoa microfinance institution. She is the leader of N13TSơnPSơn group, which consists of 4 members.

With her business profit, Hạnh hopes for her family to be healthy and happy, for her business to do well and to have enough money for her children to go to school.

loans.use: to expand her business tailoring clothes and purchase more materials to sew more clothes

loans.name: Engracia

texts.en: Engracia is 65 years old. Although her children are all grown up, she continue to work hard for an income. She is asking a loan to support her hog raising business. She will use it to buy feed and piglets. Engracia knows the importance of making the most of her time since she has to wait for 4 months before she can sell her animals. In the future, Engracia plans to expand her business so she can have a higher return of investment.

loans.use: to buy feed and piglets

loans.name: Geralyn Vhie

texts.en:
Geralyn is a new member of Center for Community Transformation. She signed up on March 24, 2015 and is a resident of Comm Quezon City, Philippines.

Buying and selling of tarpaulin covers is her source of income, together with her husband, Larry, who’s helping her with the business. The product is used on vehicles or other structures as a protection against sunlight or rain.

They've been in this business for already five years now. Their monthly earnings are approximately PHP 12,000, and that is used to support their children’s education and for their daily expenses.

According to Geralyn, during the past six months the business has been continually growing and she considered it as a blessing from God. Another answered prayer was when she found out about Center for Community Transformation (CCT) and how it nurtures aspiring entrepreneurs.

She decided to apply for a PHP 10,000 loan to expand her stock of tarpaulin covers and buy different kinds of shoelaces so that customers will have a variety of designs and sizes to choose from, which will increase profits and daily sales.

Geralyn spares time to attend her CCT fellowship group that consists of 15 to 30 members, where she hears the word of God and testimonies from partners; this made Geralyn become strong spiritually and dependent to God on every occasion.

loans.use: to expand her stock of tarpaulin covers and buy different kinds of shoelaces so that customers will have a variety of designs and sizes to choose from

loans.name: Angele

texts.en:
Angele is a married woman with four children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Angele is 35 years old and has four children who are in school.

Angele has a buy and sell rice business in the Philippines. Angele requested a PHP 8000 loan amount through NWTF to buy additional sacks of rice to sell for her business.

Angele has been in this business for 5 years. In the future, Angele would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional sacks of rice to sell for her business

loans.name: Julina

texts.en:
Julina is a hardworking woman entrepreneur with four children.

She earns a living by pig fattening in the Philippines. She is borrowing PHP 15000 through NWTF to buy feeds and other supplies to raise her pigs.

She successfully paid back her previous loan, and now she has requested an additional loan to further build her business.

Julina dreams that one day she will be able to repair and renovate her family home.

loans.use: to buy feeds and other supplies to raise her pigs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy rings, bracelets, chains, and earrings.

loans.name: Visitacion

texts.en:
As a married parent of seven children, Visitacion works hard to support her family.

She has a rice retailing business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from buy and sell charcoal.  Visitacion is borrowing PHP 20000 through NWTF to purchase additional sacks of rice to sell for her rice retailing business.

Visitacion has been sustaining her business activities through her past 24 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional sacks of rice to sell

loans.name: Manal

texts.en: Manal is a 30-year-old married woman and the mother of four children. Manal sells decoration pieces from her home to supplement her husband's income, as he earns a small salary working as a salesman. Manal is applying for this loan in order to increase her stock of decoration pieces and  begin selling home products.

loans.use: to increase her stock of decoration pieces and begin selling home products.

loans.name: Maria Lyn

texts.en:
Maria Lyn is a widowed woman with five children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Maria Lyn is 42 years old and has four children are currently in school.

Maria Lyn has a dried fish making business in the Philippines. Maria Lyn requested a PHP 5000 loan amount through NWTF to buy more fish, sacks of salt, net and other materials for her dried fish making business.

Maria Lyn has been in this business for 3 years. She would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy more fish, sacks of salt, net and other materials for her dried fish making business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more baby goats to inflate her sales and profits alongside.

loans.name: Judy

texts.en:
Judy is 37 years old, married and blessed with 2 children. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in the year 2013 to benefit from the trainings especially enterprise development.
She is a vegetable farmer and operates a greengrocer store. She also operates a salon to supplement her income.

She is borrowing Kiva loan to buy fertilizers hence boost vegetables production for increased income and be able to meet her basic needs e.g. food and clothing

She is grateful to Kiva and their lenders for the financial support.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers hence boost vegetables production for increased income and enable her to meet some basic needs.

loans.name: Shaheen

texts.en:
Shaheen is 56 years old woman, with 3 children, she lives in Rawalpindi, Pakistan. Her husband has been working in public sector organization for many years. Shaheen is also providing sewing services and earn the income to contribute with her husband to manage the house hold.

She is needs different kinds of goods e.g needles, threads, pieces of cloth, machine oil etc for her business purpose, but due to insufficient financial means she is unable to purchase these accessories. Therefore she has applied for Kiva loan from its field partner BRAC Pakistan. This loan will enable her to purchase these above accessories and also helpful for her to increase monthly sales and profit by providing better sewing services.

Shaheen is very thankful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to increase her tailoring business.

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn is a 37-year-old woman with an 18-year-old son. She supports them by weaving baskets and raising pigs. Her business also allows her to help her husband who works as a carpenter. She is asking for a loan to buy wicker, buri, piglets and feed.

Marilyn anticipates that with the help of a loan, she can produce more baskets and raise more pigs for a profit. She plans to expand her business and make it more successful.

loans.use: to buy wicker, buri, piglets and feed.

loans.name: Merilyn

texts.en: Merilyn is a married woman with four children ages five to fifteen. It is a quite struggle for her since she does not earn enough from farming and hog raising. She would like to expand but she is struggling to make it possible. She is requesting a loan from CEVI, a Kiva Partner to buy corn (maize) seeds, fertilizer, piglets and feed.  Merilyn hope to earn better through her loan so that her children can go to College in the future.

loans.use: to buy corn (maize) seeds, fertilizer, piglets and feed

loans.name: Srorn

texts.en:
Srorn, 30, lives in a community in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia. She has only one child. To make a living and support the family, she has been involved in a farming business for more than 10 years. She grows banana and sells her agricultural product to the local dealers and customers in the market. The net profit that she can generate is USD 3.00 a day, on average.

In this farming season, she is lacking money to buy some farm supplies for her banana plantation. To continue her farming, she is borrowing some money from Kiva now to buy farm supplies like fertilizers, seeds and insecticides. She is thankful to lenders for the financial support. She is awaiting your kindness.

loans.use: to buy farm supplies like fertilizers, seeds and insecticides

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en: Daniel is a married man. He has one child. He describes himself as honest. He operates a motorcycle transportation business where he transports customers. He has been involved in this business for three years. His business is located in a busy place and his primary customers are locals. He describes his biggest business challenge to be insufficient funds. He will use the Kes. 20,000 loan to service and maintain his motorcycle.

loans.use: to service and maintain his motorcycle.

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en: Jackline is a married woman with 3 children. For the past 3 years, she has operated a retail business where she sells clothes. Her business is located in an area with potential and she serves a wide variety of customers. She describes her biggest business challenge to be insufficient funds. She will use the 25,000 KES loan to buy more stock of clothes. Her business goal is to be a major supplier of clothes within 5 years. She hopes that in the future, the business will grow. This is her third loan with SMEP Microfinance bank.

loans.use: buy more stock of clothes.

loans.name: Florencia

texts.en:
Her name is Florencia, aged 59, resident of Gen. Trias, Cavite, Philippines. She is happily married to Isidro, a chief cook. To help her husband make a living and save up for their old age, Florencia thought of putting up a "Smart Padala" Center.

A "Smart Padala" business is like a small remittance center where people can send and receive cash as long as they are registered with Smart Money. Filipinos who work in industrial zones or manufacturing companies regularly send money to their families and relatives who live in the provinces.

To help her operate her business, Florencia is requesting a PHP 20,000 loan to purchase a new mobile phone and pay for money credits from banks to use in her funds transfer business. She is happy with the initial outcome of her money remittance business. Filipinos prefer to go to a Smart Padala Center rather than the other older Money Remittance Center for its cheaper fees.

Florencia believes that her fund transfer business is going to be more successful in the coming years as more manufacturing companies are being built in their area. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for a new mobile phone and money credits for her money remittance business.

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en: Lolita has run a general store for many  years and  earns enough to sustain the cost of living. She had maintained and improved the business and successfully repaid her previous loan. She will use the loan to buy additional grocery goods to sell. She plans to use the additional profit  to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more goods to sell

loans.name: Loreta

texts.en:
As a married parent of three children, Loreta works hard to support her family.

She has a business farming vegetables in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from vegetable vending. Loreta is borrowing PHP 5,000 through NWTF to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies for her business farming vegetables.

She successfully repaid her previous loan and now she has requested another loan to further build her businesses.

Loreta has been sustaining her business activities through her past three loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Aida

texts.en:
As a married parent of four children, Aida works hard to support her family.

She has a food vending business in the Philippines, she also earns additional income from direct selling of Avon products. Aida is borrowing PHP 25,000 through NWTF to buy ingredients like margarine, sugar, sweet potatoes and milk for her food vending business.

She successfully repaid her previous loan and now she has requested an additional loan to further build her business.

Aida has been sustaining her business activities through her past 26 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy ingredients like margarine, sugar, sweet potatoes, and milk.

loans.name: Melinda

texts.en:
Melinda is a married woman with one child. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Melinda is 40 years old and has one child still in school.

Melinda has a buy and sell frozen foods business in the Philippines. Melinda requested a PHP 10000 loan amount through NWTF to buy additional frozen foods like hot dogs, sausage, meat and other frozen foods to sell.

Melinda has been in this business for 2 years. She would like to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy additional frozen foods like hot dogs, sausage, meat and other frozen foods to sell

loans.name: Melisa

texts.en:
Melisa is a married woman with six children. She is a very hard working entrepreneur. Melisa is 40 years old and has three children are presently in school.

Melisa has a dried fish making business in the Philippines. Melisa requested a PHP 5000 loan amount through NWTF to buy more fish, sacks of salt, net and other materials for her dried fish making business.

Melisa has been in this business for 2 years. She would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy more fish, sacks of salt, net and other materials for her dried fish making business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy gynecology instruments and a bed for her medical clinic.

loans.name: Siragi

texts.en:
Siragi is a hardworking married man living in Kamwenge, Uganda. He is a camera man where he takes human photos, covers videos and supplements this work with crop farming.

This has enabled him to educate his children. His desire is to expand his business and become prominent in the business, but it has been made difficult by the challenge of different seasonal factors.

loans.use: to buy new equipment to use to take photos of people and events and also use modern video

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy new goods for his grocery store.

loans.name: Mujeres Triunfadoras Group

texts.es: Soledad de 50 años de edad es soltera y tiene 02 hijos. Ella Pertenece a la Alcancía Comunal “mujeres triunfadoras” la cual lo conforman 05 socias que trabajan honradamente y con ganas de mejorar su calidad de vida. Ella hace más de 2 años que brinda servicio de cajera de microbús el cual le va bien. Gracias a su constante dedicación logro sacar adelante a  su familia. Su mayor deseo es de poder terminar de construir su casa es por ello que solicito el crédito para la compra de ladrillos para que pueda terminar de construir su vivienda y así darles una mejor calidad de vida a sus hijos. La Alcancía “mujeres triunfadoras” agradece a los Inversionistas de Kiva por el apoyo brindado. Soledad se encuentra en la parte posterior es la primera del lado derecho está de pie viste chompa color rojo.
texts.en:
Soledad, 50 years old, is single and has 2 children. She belongs to the "Mujeres Triunfadoras" [Triumphant Women] Community Bank, which is comprised of 5 members who work honorably and with a desire to improve their quality of life.

For two years, Soledad has been working as a minibus conductor, and it is going well for her. Thanks to her constant dedication, she has been able to get her family ahead.

Her greatest desire is to be able to finish building her house. That is why she is applying for a loan to buy bricks so that she can finish building her house and give her children a better quality of life.

The Mujeres Triunfadoras Community Bank is grateful to Kiva investors for the support. In the photo, Soledad is in the back, the first from the right. She is standing and wearing a red sweater.

loans.use: to buy bricks.

loans.name: Juvy

texts.en:
A "sari-sari store" is a business found in the Philippines which means “variety”. Most Filipinos preferred this type of business because it is home based.

Juvy is a 53-year-old resident of Muntinlupa City, Philippines. Her husband, Dionisio, is a call center agent. They helping each other to earn a living. Juvy wish to expand her variety store and provide product choices to her customers. She is continually formulating ways and marketing strategies for the business’ success since these really helped her sustain their daily expenses and support her 3 children in school.

The capital that she has on hand is not enough to buy all of the products or items needed for the business. She decided to apply for 10,000 PHP to run the business and buy grocery items and bottled drinks or her mini canteen. This would be a vast help for the business.

Juvy meets regularly with her co-fellowship members to share her life’s testimony, experience on the business, and to draw strength and inspiration from the fellowship and listen to the Word of God. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 members. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social relationship with other partners, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy a variety of grocery items and bottled drinks for her mini canteen.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase feed for her pigs.

loans.name: Simheng

texts.en: Simheng is a  31-year-old married man who lives in a rural area of Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia. He manages and operates a farm located near his house. He grows rice and has sold his agricultural products to local dealers for 10 years. On average, he is able to make an income of USD 3.00 a day.The earning that he receives from his faming is every low. He wants to start one more business as a supplementary income. However, the limited capital doesn’t allow him to do so. That is why he is applying for a KIVA loan to begin a business to buy and sell scrap. This loan will allow him to have one more source of income  to help remove poverty form his life. He thanks all lenders for their financial support of poor people.

loans.use: to invest in a business.

loans.name: Nilda

texts.en:
Nilda is 57 years old, widowed and has three children.

Nilda is in the agricultural business, pig-fattening in the Philippines. Nilda requested a PHP 15,000 loan through NWTF to buy feed, vitamins, vaccines and other supplies to raise her pigs.

Nilda has been in this business for three years now, and has borrowed six times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

She would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy feed, vitamins, vaccines and other supplies to raise her pigs.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy more cattle for sale.

loans.name: Tuyen's Group

texts.en:
Tuyen, 38 years old, is a Thai ethnic man. He currently lives with his wife and his son in Mai Son district, Son La province. His family’s main income is from cultivation and pig breeding, so the income is after deducting all costs is just enough to cover the living expenses of the family and to save a small amount.

He intends to expand the breeding by raising pig for meat, but he does not have enough money. Therefore, he wants to take a loan for this purpose.

He will work hard to get money to repay the loan for M7-MFI on time. He hopes that the loan amount will help his family invest effectively in breeding with high productivity and the next pig herd will bring his family a considerable profit.

loans.use: to expand his pig breeding business

loans.name: Tareq

texts.en: Tareq is a 33 years old man living in Um Qais in Irbid northern Jordan where he started his family and had his first child. Tareq has a hobby making mosaic art, but he found that it is not enough to support a family specially after the Syrian conflict where Irbid was one of the cities affected by it since it is close to the Syrian borders. So he opened a small market where he has a section for selling food, and another for selling stationary items, and used that section to show and sell what he make of mosaic art in his free time. Tareq is applying for a loan to increase the food products he is selling like rice, sugar, food cans, etc, and support the section of stationary with more books to prepare for back to school season.

loans.use: to increase the food products he is selling like rice, sugar and food cans and to support the stationery section by buying more books to prepare for back to school season.

loans.name: Vellur Jlg -005 Group

texts.en:
Janaki is a 34-year-old woman who represents the group Vellur JLG -005. She lives with her family in the Tiruchirapalli district of Tamil Nadu. Janaki works as a laborer in addition and also manages the household chores. Her wages are not sufficient to financially support her family. The income generated is not enough to make ends meet. She finds it hard to bear the household expenses and the cost of education for her children.

Janaki has decided to start her own business and make foot mats. She has been trained and is now ready to start a business of her own. She seeks an enterprise loan to buy the raw material required to initiate her business. She believes that it will make her life easier and better.

She leads a group of women who come from similar backgrounds and lack the funds to start their respective businesses. The loan will be utilized to kick start their respective businesses. They are grateful to you for your loan.

loans.use: to start a business to make foot mats.

loans.name: Mettupalayam Group

texts.en:
Parimala is a 27-year-old woman who represents a group of 5 women. She lives in the Tiruchirapalli district of Tamil Nadu.

Parimala had been primarily involved in daily wage earning, but the income generated from it was not enough to make ends meet. She struggles to bear the household expenses and other necessities.

Parimala has decided to start her own business of Kundhan jewel-making since she had been trained for it. She wishes to buy the raw material required to start her business, but lacks the funds. She seeks an enterprise loan to initiate the business, which will help the family lead a better life.

Your loan will help this group start businesses of their own and financially contribute to their families.

loans.use: to buy raw materials to start her Kundhan jewel-making business.

loans.name: Khalida

texts.en:
Khalida is a 51-year-old active borrower of BRAC Pakistan, residing in Rawalpindi, Pakistan with her spouse and 1 child. Her husband has run a tailoring shop in the local market for 9 years. Her husband is responsible for meeting the needs of the entire family.

Khalida's husband needs to buy fabric, laces, needles, and sewing machine accessories. However, he does not have the means to buy these items. Khalida has applied for a Kiva loan from its field partner BRAC Pakistan. She will use the loan to financially assist her husband to purchase these tailoring accessories and meet his business needs. He will then be able to earn a more profitable income.

Khalida is very thankful to KIVA and BRAC Pakistan for this financial assistance.

loans.use: Khalida's husband wanted to increase his tailoring business.

loans.name: Karikali Jlg - 009 Group

texts.en: Dhanalakshmi is a 39-year-old woman who represents a group of 5 women. She lives in Tiruchirapalli district of Tamil Nadu. Dhanalaksmi has four members in her family. She usually engages in daily wage earning to support the family. The monthly income of the family is Rs. 10,000 which makes it difficult to provide the basic needs of the family. Dhanalakshmi wishes to start her own business to support the family. As she has been trained in making wire bags, she wishes to buy some raw material and start her own wire bag-making business. At the moment she lacks the funds required to initiate her business, so she is seeking an enterprise loan to begin her business. Similarly, the other members also need a loan to start their respective businesses.

loans.use: To buy the raw materials required to start her wire bag-making business.

loans.name: Jlg-009-Keelathaliyampatti Group

texts.en:
Thirty-nine-year-old Jegadhambal from Kulithalai, in rural Tamil Nadu, has no toilet at home or in the immediate vicinity. Jegadhambal's family of five is one of the millions affected by rural India's sanitation crisis.

Jegadhambal is married and is a mother of three children. Her family does not have access to a toilet at home. Without access to a toilet, her family has to walk long distances to relieve themselves in the false privacy of dense bushes or isolated fields. Due to this lack of sanitation facilities, the family member are at risk of infection and fall ill often, spending a significant portion of their savings on medical expenses each month. The women and daughters in her family are exposed to the additional risk of molestation.

Joining hands with three others whose families face similar problems due to a lack of sanitation facilities, Jegadhambal has formed a group and is hoping to address this issue. Taking matters into their own hands, Jegadhambal and her group want to build toilets for themselves in their own homes. They seek a loan of 42000 INR to cover the cost of raw materials and labor for constructing these toilets. Your loan will help these families access basic sanitation, improved health, and safety.

loans.use: To construct toilets and improve sanitation facilities in their homes

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali is a 48-year-old married man from Rafah city, which is located in the Gaza Strip, and has had an economic blockade imposed by the Israeli authorities since 2007. He is the father of two sons and one daughter. He works as an employee in the public sector where he gets a low income. Ali also has a store where he sells fruits and vegetables. Ali took a USD loan from FATEN. This loan will help him to buy a new inventory (fruits and vegetables) for his store. With this loan, Ali can increase his sales and also his profit. Ali appears in the photo.

loans.use: to buy a new inventory (fruits and vegetables) for his store.

loans.name: Ma. Eleonor

texts.en:
Ma. Eleonor has managed an accounting firm for 20 years and has employees and an office. She’s so grateful that someone introduced Center for Community Transformation (CCT) to her. She wants to extend her warmest appreciation to lenders for the monetary support and to CCT for approving her previous loan which helped her a lot in the business. The program also conducts seminars and free lectures on how to grow a business.

In keeping up with advanced technology, Ma. Eleonor uses computers for recording transactions and preparing reports. Part of her services to her clients is submission of documents to the Bureau of Internal Revenue (BIR) which recently upgraded its system, and this necessitates an upgrade of Ma. Eleonor's computers as well. Ma.Eleonor applied for another loan of 50, 000 PHP to buy bond paper, filing cabinets, ink for the printer, an air conditioner, office supplies, and office tables. She also needs to upgrade the computer system.

Despite being busy managing the business, Ma.Eleonor spares time attending CCT group fellowship that consists of 10-15 individuals to gain strength spiritually and hear testimonies from other CCT partners. She is able to hear God’s word, study the Word of God, build social relationship with other partners, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to buy office supplies and upgrade the computer.

loans.name: Bahati

texts.en:
Bahati is a married woman who describes herself as innovative. She has operated a retail business to sell clothing for 2 years. Her business is located in a competitive place and her primary customers are local people. She describes her biggest business challenge as inadequate capital.

She will use the 90,000 KES loan to buy more stock of clothes.This will enable her to increase her stock and profits. Her business goal is to open other business outlets within 5 years. She hopes that in the future, she will expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more stock of clothes.

loans.name: Lennity

texts.en:
Lennity is a married woman with 6 children who describes herself as innovative. She operates a farm to raise cows and grow crops. She has been involved in this business for 10 years. Her business is located in an area good for dairy farming and her primary customers are local people.

She describes her biggest business challenge as having inadequate animal feed. She will use the 40,000 KES to buy animal feed and fertilizer.

Her business goal is to buy more land and cows within 5 years. She hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy animal feed and fertilizer.

loans.name: Elsie

texts.en:
Elsie is a hard-working female entrepreneur with four children. She buys and sells charcoal and firewood in the Philippines and has requested a 12,000 PHP loan through NWTF to buy additional stock of charcoal and firewood to sell.

She successfully paid back her previous loan, and now she has requested an additional loan to further build her business.

Elsie dreams that one day she will be able to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy additional stock of charcoal and firewood to sell.

loans.name: Ageteraine Buhungiro Group

texts.en:
Mathias, aged 49, is a resident of Kagadi, Uganda. He is very hard-working and a father to six children, and he lives together with his wife. Mathias trades in waragi (a distilled beverage) as his major source of income, which he supplements with income from farming. Mathias started trading in waragi far back in the year 2003 to help him earn a living.

Mathias is a member of a group in which members guarantee one another in order to earn a living. Mathias needs the loan to add capital to his business.

Mathias desires to have an educated family. He is, however, faced with a challenge of price fluctuations.

loans.use: to buy jerrycans of waragi.

loans.name: Valaiyapatti Jlg-002 Group

texts.en:
Malathi is a 39-year-old woman who represents the group Valaiyapatti JLG-002. She lives in Karur district of Tamil Nadu with her family. Malathi is a laborer and earns an income which is not sufficient to meet the needs of the family members. It is challenging for her to manage the monthly household expenses.

Malathi wants to start her own business of millet-based food products; she received training. She believes that the business can help her family lead a better life. Malathi lacks the funds to buy raw materials to start her own business. She leads a group of women who also aim to start their own businesses but lack the capital. Your loan will help these women realize their entrepreneurial dreams.

They thank you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to start her business of selling millet products

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more foods like posho, cassava and cooking oil for her restaurant.

loans.name: Jlg-008(A)-Pudhupalayam Group

texts.en:
Twenty-six-year-old Girija has formed a self-help group with her friends in Kulithalai, in the rural part of Karur, in Tamil Nadu. She is married and the mother of two children. She works hard to sustain her family but is not able to manage the expenses on her limited income.

To add to all the hardships, her family does not have access to a toilet at home. Without access to a toilet, her family has to walk long distances to relieve themselves in the false privacy of dense bushes or isolated fields. Due to this lack of sanitation facilities, the family members are at risk of infection and fall ill often, spending a significant portion of their savings on medical expenses each month. The women and daughters in her family are exposed to the additional risk of molestation.

Seeking to improve their situation, the group members are seeking a loan of INR 42,000 to build toilets in their homes. Your loan will help their families access basic sanitation for improved health, and safety.

loans.use: to improve sanitation facilities in her home by installing a toilet.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more  fish to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a dairy cow for milk production and supplement his farming activity.

loans.name: Jlg-012-Keela Andar Street Group

texts.en:
Thirty-seven-year-old Amsavalli has formed a self-help group with her friends in Kulithalai, in the rural part of Karur, in Tamil Nadu. All four group members work hard to support their families and save diligently. However, their finances are not adequate for them to access basic necessities like toilets in their homes.

Amsavalli's family of four is one such family. The family members have to trek long distances at dawn to use the fields to relieve themselves. Due to this lack of sanitation facilities, her family is at risk of infection and often falls ill, spending a significant portion of their savings on medical expenses each month. The women and daughters in their family are exposed to the additional risk of molestation.

Taking matters into their own hands, Amsavalli and her group want to build toilets for themselves in their own homes. They seek a loan of INR 56,000 to cover the cost of raw materials and labor for constructing these toilets. Your loan will help these four hardworking rural Indian families to access basic sanitation, and consequently, safety, improved health, medical savings, and improved productivity.

loans.use: to build a toilet in her home.

loans.name: Jlg-014-Keela Andar Street Group

texts.en:
The sanitation crisis in India is a result of poor infrastructure and lack of education. Thirty-two-year-old Jothilakshmi, living in Kulithalai, in the state of Tamil Nadu, has understood the importance of having a toilet at home. But she does not have the means to build one since she has to manage all expenses with a limited monthly income of INR 12,100. Without access to a toilet, her family has to walk long distances to relieve themselves in the false privacy of dense bushes or isolated fields.

Due to this lack of sanitation facilities, the family member are at risk of infection and fall ill often, spending a significant portion of their savings on medical expenses each month. The women and daughters in her family are exposed to the additional risk of molestation. Access to a toilet will mean privacy and peace of mind for Jothilakshmi and her family. It will also mean they no longer need to walk long distances, especially when they are sick. So, together, the group is seeking a loan of INR 42,000 to build a toilet in their respective homes. Your loan will help these three hardworking rural Indian families to access basic sanitation, and consequently, safety, improved health, medical savings, and improved productivity.

loans.use: to fund the installation of a toilet in her home.

loans.name: Believe In Ourselves - N1Ttrà1Qtrung Group

texts.en:
Mrs Tâm is 33 years old and she is marrie She has had a retail business selling dry food and general things for 8 years. Tâm lives in Quang Xuong district, a rural town in Thanh Hoa province. Her family is a low-income household in village, moreover the market need is low in this region.

The main hardship that Tâm faces is lack of capital. She is requesting a loan to purchase more items for her grocery store and resell.

In 2013, Tâm joined Thanh Hoa microfinance institution to improve her business. Tâm has successfully repaid 3 loans from Thanh Hoa microfinance institution.

With her business profit, Tâm hopes for her business to do well, for her family to be healthy and happy, and for her children to go to school.

loans.use: to purchase more items for her grocery store and resell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy products for the snack stand.

loans.name: Eva

texts.en:
Eva is 57 years old, married and has five children.

Eva is in the agricultural business in the Philippines. She requested a PHP 13,000 loan through NWTF to buy additional sacks of feed for her pigs.

Eva has been doing this for 10 years now, and has borrowed six times in the past from NWTF to sustain it.

In the future, Eva would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy additional sacks of feed for her pigs.

loans.name: Floramey

texts.en:
Floramey is 26 years old and married with two children.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to purchase additional stocks like sugar, sardines, oil, etc., to sell.

Floramey has borrowed and repaid six loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for five years and also earns an income from vegetable vending.

She aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional stocks like sugar, sardines, oil, etc., to sell.

loans.name: Sankari

texts.en:
Sankari, a 52-year-old entrepreneur, lives with her husband and three grown up son in Falakata. Among the sons, two are associated with the clothing business and the other one is a Toto van driver.

Sankari and her husband are engaged in the batasha making and selling business. They make batasha in their home and supply it to the local shops and in their neighborhood. Batasha is a semi-spherical crispy sugar drop candy. It is mostly used as Prasad in temples and in different Hindu festivals.

There is a high demand for batasha in their local area, and thus they want to develop their business to satisfy the demands of their customers. However, they need financial aid to invest in the business.

Thus as a responsible wife, Sankari applied for a loan from Kiva’s partner, BJS. She will use the loan to buy the ingredients to make batasha. She hopes that this business loan will give a boost to their micro-enterprise and as well generate sufficient income, with which she can easily bear the household expenses.

Sankari is really grateful towards her lenders for their kind support.

loans.use: to buy ingredients for making batasha (sugar drop candy) for their existing business.

loans.name: Shabnam

texts.en:
Shabnam is 35 years old, a married woman and a mother to a son and daughter. Her husband is a driver by profession and provides transportation services using his three-wheeled rickshaw. He has been driving a rickshaw for many years to meet the family's expenses, but now it requires proper maintenance to keep it in its functional routine.

For this reason, Shabnam has applied for a loan from Kiva’s field partner BRAC Pakistan for her husband. He wants to buy new tires and do a little bit of engine maintenance on his vehicle. This will help him drive more smoothly and provide a better transportation service to his passengers. She is hopeful that this loan will be a productive one for her husband and will bring positive changes to his business.

SHABNAM gives thanks to Kiva and to its field partner BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to help her husband purchase new rickshaw tires and do engine maintenance.

loans.name: Nasreen

texts.en:
Nasreen is a 36-year-old woman. She lives in Rawalpindi, Pakistan. As for her three sons, her children are studying. Her husband has been running his own business of clothes selling for 10 years. Her husband is the only one responsible for feeding the entire family and managing the household. Her husband needs to purchase different types of clothes in bulk for reselling purposes, but due to insufficient financial means he is unable to purchase these clothes. Therefore Nasreen is applying for a Kiva loan from its field partner BRAC Pakistan so that she can assist her husband to purchase these clothes in bulk for his business. Her husband can also increase the size of his business and earn maximum profit with the help of this loan amount.

Nasreen is very thankful to Kiva and BRAC Pakistan.

loans.use: to help her husband increase his clothing business.

loans.name: Jlg-001-Malaiyappanagar Group

texts.en:
Malarmani has formed a self-help group with her friends in the rural part of Karur, in Tamil Nadu. She works hard to support her family with a limited income of INR 8500, and saves diligently. However, the current income is not adequate for her family to access basic necessities like a toilet in their home. They have to trek long distances at dawn to use the fields to relieve themselves. These unsanitary practices make them vulnerable to infections, and the lack of privacy exposes them to molestation or worse. Sometimes, the monthly salary is spent on health problems caused by lack of toilets; hence leaving little for other expenses.

Taking advantage of the awareness initiatives, the group members now seek a loan of INR 42,000 to build toilets in their homes.
